message.content:
Find guide sections that have empty or missing product recommendations.

1. Read all guide files in src/data/guides/
2. For each guide, check every section for:
   - sections with productIds: [] (empty array)
   - sections with products: [] (empty array)
   - sections that mention products in content but have no productIds
3. Look at the guide structure and identify sections that SHOULD have products but don't
4. Check if any guide has a "Recommended Products" type section with no actual products

For each issue found, suggest which products from the registry would be appropriate to add.

Be comprehensive - go through every guide file and every section.

content.text: I'll help you find guide sections with empty or missing product recommendations. Let me start by exploring the guide files structure.

1→/**
     2→ * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
     3→ * Humor Level: High (30%)
     4→ */
     5→
     6→import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7→
     8→export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
     9→  id: 'mindset',
    10→  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
    11→  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
    12→  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
    13→  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
    14→  icon: 'Brain',
    15→  humorLevel: 'high',
    16→  estimatedReadTime: 8,
    17→  order: 1,
    18→  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
    19→  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
    20→  productIds: [],
    21→  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
    22→  heroMedia: {
    23→    id: 'mindset-hero',
    24→    type: 'image',
    25→    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    26→    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    27→    placement: 'hero',
    28→  },
    29→  sections: [
    30→    {
    31→      id: 'intro',
    32→      title: 'The Real Talk',
    33→      humorLevel: 'high',
    34→      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.
    35→
    36→But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**
    37→
    38→They're either:
    39→- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
    40→- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
    41→- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
    42→- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)
    43→
    44→This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
    45→      media: [
    46→        {
    47→          id: 'mindset-intro',
    48→          type: 'image',
    49→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
    50→          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
    51→          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
    52→          placement: 'inline',
    53→        },
    54→        {
    55→          id: 'level-up-gif',
    56→          type: 'gif',
    57→          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
    58→          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
    59→          caption: 'Time to level up',
    60→          placement: 'inline',
    61→        },
    62→      ],
    63→    },
    64→    {
    65→      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
    66→      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
    67→      humorLevel: 'high',
    68→      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.
    69→
    70→**This ain't it, chief.**
    71→
    72→The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.
    73→
    74→Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.
    75→
    76→**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
    77→      tips: [
    78→        'Done is better than perfect',
    79→        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
    80→        'Start before you feel ready'
    81→      ],
    82→      media: [
    83→        {
    84→          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
    85→          type: 'image',
    86→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
    87→          alt: 'Planning and action',
    88→          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
    89→          placement: 'inline',
    90→        },
    91→      ],
    92→    },
    93→    {
    94→      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
    95→      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
    96→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
    97→      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.
    98→
    99→Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:
   100→
   101→| Change | Timeline |
   102→|--------|----------|
   103→| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
   104→| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
   105→| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
   106→| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
   107→| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |
   108→
   109→**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**
   110→
   111→Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
   112→      warnings: [
   113→        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
   114→        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
   115→      ],
   116→    },
   117→    {
   118→      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
   119→      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
   120→      humorLevel: 'high',
   121→      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
   122→- Won the genetic lottery
   123→- Have professional lighting in every photo
   124→- Are on gear and won't admit it
   125→- Use filters/editing
   126→- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"
   127→
   128→**This is NPC behavior.**
   129→
   130→Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.
   131→
   132→Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
   133→      tips: [
   134→        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
   135→        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
   136→        'Follow for information, not comparison'
   137→      ],
   138→    },
   139→    {
   140→      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
   141→      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
   142→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   143→      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."
   144→
   145→The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
   146→- Miracle supplements that do nothing
   147→- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
   148→- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics
   149→
   150→**Here's what actually works:**
   151→1. Sleep 7-9 hours
   152→2. Eat enough protein
   153→3. Lift weights
   154→4. Use sunscreen
   155→5. Stay lean
   156→6. Groom yourself
   157→
   158→That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
   159→    },
   160→    {
   161→      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
   162→      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
   163→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   164→      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
   165→You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
   166→You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.
   167→
   168→**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**
   169→
   170→Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.
   171→
   172→Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.
   173→
   174→**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
   175→      tips: [
   176→        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
   177→        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
   178→        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
   179→      ],
   180→    },
   181→    {
   182→      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
   183→      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
   184→      humorLevel: 'high',
   185→      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
   186→You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
   187→You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.
   188→
   189→**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**
   190→
   191→Here's the priority order:
   192→1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
   193→2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
   194→3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
   195→4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery
   196→
   197→Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.
   198→
   199→Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
   200→      warnings: [
   201→        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
   202→        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
   203→      ],
   204→    },
   205→    {
   206→      id: 'the-real-strategy',
   207→      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
   208→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   209→      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:
   210→
   211→**1. Accept the timeline**
   212→You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.
   213→
   214→**2. Build systems, not goals**
   215→"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.
   216→
   217→**3. Track ruthlessly**
   218→Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.
   219→
   220→**4. Iterate slowly**
   221→Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.
   222→
   223→**5. Focus on the 80/20**
   224→20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
   225→- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
   226→- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
   227→- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)
   228→
   229→**Nail these before anything else.**`,
   230→      tips: [
   231→        'Progress compounds over time',
   232→        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
   233→        'Document everything so you can see the change'
   234→      ],
   235→      media: [
   236→        {
   237→          id: 'strategy-visual',
   238→          type: 'image',
   239→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
   240→          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
   241→          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
   242→          placement: 'inline',
   243→        },
   244→      ],
   245→    },
   246→    {
   247→      id: 'closing',
   248→      title: 'Lock In',
   249→      humorLevel: 'high',
   250→      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.
   251→
   252→You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.
   253→
   254→The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.
   255→
   256→**Your move.**
   257→
   258→Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
   259→    },
   260→  ],
   261→};
   262→

/**
 * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
 * Humor Level: High (30%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'mindset',
  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
  icon: 'Brain',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 1,
  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'mindset-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Real Talk',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.

But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**

They're either:
- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)

This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'mindset-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'level-up-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
          caption: 'Time to level up',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.

**This ain't it, chief.**

The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.

Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.

**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
      tips: [
        'Done is better than perfect',
        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
        'Start before you feel ready'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Planning and action',
          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.

Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:

| Change | Timeline |
|--------|----------|
| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |

**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**

Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
      warnings: [
        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
- Won the genetic lottery
- Have professional lighting in every photo
- Are on gear and won't admit it
- Use filters/editing
- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"

**This is NPC behavior.**

Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.

Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
      tips: [
        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
        'Follow for information, not comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
- Miracle supplements that do nothing
- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics

**Here's what actually works:**
1. Sleep 7-9 hours
2. Eat enough protein
3. Lift weights
4. Use sunscreen
5. Stay lean
6. Groom yourself

That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.

**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**

Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.

Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.

**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
      tips: [
        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.

**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**

Here's the priority order:
1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery

Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.

Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
      warnings: [
        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-real-strategy',
      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

**1. Accept the timeline**
You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.

**2. Build systems, not goals**
"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.

**3. Track ruthlessly**
Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.

**4. Iterate slowly**
Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.

**5. Focus on the 80/20**
20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)

**Nail these before anything else.**`,
      tips: [
        'Progress compounds over time',
        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
        'Document everything so you can see the change'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'strategy-visual',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'closing',
      title: 'Lock In',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.

You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.

The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.

**Your move.**

Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
    },
  ],
};

    58→**The Protocol:**

    88→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
    89→      content: `Crusty, chapped lips are sabotaging your entire face. The fix costs $5.

    98→
    99→**Common Mistakes:**

   111→      content: `Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation is an instant mog-killer. Nobody's going to tell you—they'll just slowly lose attraction and not know why.
   112→
   113→**The Protocol:**
   114→- Trim nose hairs weekly (Sunday maintenance)
   115→- Check ear hair too (yes, you have some)
   116→- Use a proper trimmer, not scissors (you WILL cut yourself)
   117→
   118→**The Psychology:**
   119→People rarely notice good grooming here, but they DEFINITELY notice when you neglect it. It's one of those things that can only hurt you, never help. Just eliminate it.
   120→
   121→Get a trimmer. Use it weekly. This is bare minimum NPC maintenance, and you're not an NPC.`,
   122→      products: ['nose_trimmer'],
   123→      warnings: [
   124→        "Don't use scissors inside your nose",

   126→      ],

   129→      id: 'weekly-eyebrows',
   130→      title: 'Weekly: Eyebrow Maintenance',
   131→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   132→      content: `There's a zone between "unibrow" and "Instagram influencer overplucked" that you're aiming for.
   133→
   134→**What to Do:**
   135→1. **Define the gap** — There should be clear separation between brows. Pluck strays between them.
   136→2. **Clean the edges** — Remove random hairs above and below the brow line.
   137→3. **Don't reshape** — You're cleaning, not redesigning. Keep your natural brow shape.
   138→
   139→**What NOT to Do:**
   140→- Don't thin them out (thicker brows = more masculine)

   142→- Don't touch the main body of the brow
   143→- Don't wax (too aggressive for maintenance)
   144→
   145→**The Goal:**
   146→Clean and intentional, not "did someone do your eyebrows?" If people can tell you've groomed them, you've gone too far.`,
   147→      products: ['tweezers'],
   148→      tips: [
   149→        'Pluck after shower when pores are open',
   150→        'Use natural light, bathroom lighting lies',
   151→        'Take a step back every few hairs to check balance'
   152→      ],
   153→    },
   154→    {
   155→      id: 'weekly-facial-hair',
   156→      title: 'Weekly: Facial Hair Management',
   157→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   158→      content: `Whether you're going clean-shaven, stubble, or full beard—it needs to look intentional, not accidental.
   159→
   160→**Clean-Shaven:**
   161→- Shave every 1-3 days depending on growth
   162→- Use a proper shave cream (not canned foam)
   163→- Shave with the grain first, then against if needed
   164→- Moisturize after
   165→
   166→**Stubble:**
   167→- This is the sweet spot for most faces
   168→- Maintain at 1-3mm with a trimmer
   169→- Clean up the neck and cheek lines
   170→- Edge the mustache above the lip line
   171→
   172→**Beard:**
   173→- Keep it trimmed and shaped
   174→- Define the neckline (2 fingers above Adam's apple)
   175→- Use beard oil if longer than 1 week growth
   176→- Wash it (yes, like hair)
   177→
   178→**The Key:** Whatever style you choose, it should look like a choice, not like you ran out of razors.`,
   179→      products: ['philips_oneblade', 'shaving_cream'],
   180→    },
   181→    {
   182→      id: 'nails',
   183→      title: 'Weekly: Nail Care',
   184→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   185→      content: `Women notice nails immediately. Dirty, long, or bitten nails are an instant credibility killer.
   186→
   187→**The Standard:**
   188→- Trim weekly
   189→- File rough edges (yes, men can use nail files)

   191→- Push back cuticles after shower (optional but clean look)
   192→
   193→**What You're Avoiding:**
   194→- Nails that extend past fingertips
   195→- Visible dirt under nails
   196→- Ragged, bitten edges
   197→- Hangnails
   198→
   199→**No man has ever lost points for having clean, trimmed nails. Many have lost points for the opposite.**`,
   200→      tips: [
   201→        'Cut after shower when nails are softer',
   202→        'Straight across, then round the corners slightly',
   203→        "Keep a nail brush by the sink if you work with your hands"
   204→      ],
   205→    },
   206→    {
   207→      id: 'fragrance',
   208→      title: 'Daily: Scent Protocol',
   209→      humorLevel: 'high',
   210→      content: `Stop smelling like your high school gym locker. This ain't Axe bodyspray era anymore.
   211→
   212→**The Layers:**
   213→1. **Base** — Shower daily with unscented or lightly scented soap
   214→2. **Deodorant** — Antiperspirant, applied at night (not morning)
   215→3. **Fragrance** — 2-3 sprays MAX of a quality cologne
   216→
   217→**Application:**
   218→- Spray on pulse points: wrists, neck, chest
   219→- Don't rub wrists together (breaks down scent)
   220→- Less is more—you want a "lean in" scent, not an announcement
   221→
   222→**Cologne Investment:**
   223→One quality fragrance beats five cheap ones. Bleu de Chanel or similar safe bet. Get compliments, not complaints.
   224→
   225→**The Test:** If people can smell you from more than arm's length, you've applied too much.`,
   226→      products: ['cologne_bleu'],
   227→      warnings: [
   228→        'Never spray directly on clothes (stains and alters scent)',
   229→        "Don't reapply throughout the day—your nose adapts, others can still smell it"
   230→      ],
   231→    },
   232→    {
   233→      id: 'hair',
   234→      title: 'Daily: Hair Maintenance',
   235→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   236→      content: `Your hair is a major factor in your overall look. Neglecting it shows.
   237→
   238→**Daily:**
   239→- Style it. Every day. Even if it's a 2-minute routine.
   240→- Use product appropriate to your hair type (matte for thin, pomade for thick)
   241→- Don't touch it throughout the day (transfers oil)
   242→
   243→**Every 4-6 Weeks:**
   244→- Get it cut by a real barber
   245→- Find a style that works for your face shape and hair type
   246→- Bring reference photos (they're not just for women)
   247→
   248→**Washing:**
   249→- Most guys over-wash (strips natural oils)
   250→- Every 2-3 days is usually enough
   251→- Use conditioner if your hair is longer than 1 inch
   252→
   253→**If Thinning:**
   254→- Accept it early or treat it early
   255→- Minoxidil + finasteride (consult a doctor)
   256→- Or just buzz it—a clean shave beats a comb-over every time`,
   257→      tips: [
   258→        'Find one style and master it rather than switching constantly',
   259→        'Take photos of good haircuts to show your barber',
   260→        'Products for hold: wax > pomade > gel > mousse'
   261→      ],
   262→    },
   263→    {
   264→      id: 'hair-thinning',
   265→      title: 'Hair Maintenance for Thinning Hair',
   266→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   267→      content: `If you're noticing recession or thinning, you've got two choices: treat it or accept it. There's no middle ground of denial.
   268→
   269→**Recognize the Signs Early:**
   270→- Hairline moving back at temples (receding)
   271→- Crown getting thinner (you can't see it, but others can)
   272→- More hair in the drain/pillow
   273→- Scalp visible under bright lights
   274→
   275→**The Treatment Stack (The "Big 3"):**
   276→
   277→| Treatment | What It Does | Cost |
   278→|-----------|--------------|------|
   279→| **Minoxidil 5%** | Stimulates follicles, extends growth phase | $20-40/6 months |
   280→| **Finasteride 1mg** | Blocks DHT, stops progression | $10-30/month |
   281→| **Ketoconazole Shampoo** | Anti-inflammatory, mild DHT blocker | $15/bottle |
   282→
   283→**Timeline:**
   284→- Months 1-3: Possible shedding (normal, it's working)
   285→- Months 4-6: Stabilization, slowed loss
   286→- Months 6-12: Regrowth begins for responders
   287→- Year 1+: Maintenance mode
   288→
   289→**The Decision:**
   290→If you're going to treat, start NOW. The earlier you start, the more hair you save. Once a follicle is dead, it's gone.
   291→
   292→**The Alternative:**
   293→If treatment isn't for you, own the look:
   294→- Buzz it short or shave clean
   295→- Grow a beard if you can (bald + beard is a classic look)
   296→- Get lean—face definition matters more when hair is gone
   297→- Confidence > coping
   298→
   299→We'll have a full hair loss guide coming soon. For now, don't wait—decide early.`,
   300→      tips: [
   301→        'Minoxidil can cause initial shedding—this is normal and temporary',
   302→        'Apply minoxidil to DRY scalp, not wet',
   303→        'Finasteride side effects are rare (1-2%) but discuss with doctor'
   304→      ],
   305→      warnings: [
   306→        "Don't waste money on 'hair growth' supplements—most don't work",
   307→        "Comb-overs fool nobody. Either treat it or embrace it."
   308→      ],
   309→    },
   310→    {
   311→      id: 'beard-maintenance',
   312→      title: 'Beard Maintenance & Growth',
   313→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   314→      content: `Whether you're trying to grow a beard or maintain one, here's what actually matters:
   315→
   316→**If You Can Grow One:**
   317→
   318→**Stubble (1-5mm):**
   319→- Trim every 2-3 days
   320→- This is often the most attractive option for most faces
   321→- Clean neckline 2 fingers above Adam's apple
   322→- Edge cheek line naturally
   323→
   324→**Short Beard (5-10mm):**
   325→- Trim weekly with guard
   326→- Use beard oil after showering
   327→- Keep edges sharp
   328→
   329→**Full Beard (10mm+):**
   330→- Wash with beard shampoo
   331→- Apply beard oil or balm daily
   332→- Comb/brush to train direction
   333→- Trim every 1-2 weeks for shape
   334→- Consider a barber for initial shaping
   335→
   336→**If You CAN'T Grow One (Yet):**
   337→
   338→The Minoxidil beard protocol works for many guys:
   339→1. Apply minoxidil 5% to cheeks 2x daily
   340→2. Wait 6-24 months (yes, it takes time)
   341→3. Vellus hairs → Terminal hairs
   342→4. Once terminal, effects are permanent
   343→5. Add dermarolling 0.5mm weekly for better absorption
   344→
   345→**Important:** This is off-label use. Results vary. Most guys see significant improvement, but genetics still matter.
   346→
   347→**Patchy Beard Solutions:**
   348→- Let it grow longer—length hides patches
   349→- Strategic trimming to balance density
   350→- Focus on stubble length if very patchy
   351→- Some patches fill in over time (give it 3-6 months)
   352→
   353→We'll have a full beard growth guide with protocols coming soon.`,
   354→      tips: [
   355→        'Beard growth often improves into your 30s',
   356→        'Minoxidil on beard can cause dryness—moisturize',
   357→        "Don't compare your beard at 22 to someone's at 32"
   358→      ],
   359→    },
   360→    {
   361→      id: 'checklist',
   362→      title: 'The Weekly Checklist',
   363→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   364→      content: `Print this. Put it on your bathroom mirror. No excuses.
   365→
   366→**Daily:**
   367→- [ ] Brush teeth (AM + PM)
   368→- [ ] Floss
   369→- [ ] Tongue scrape
   370→- [ ] Apply lip balm
   371→- [ ] Deodorant (night)
   372→- [ ] Style hair
   373→- [ ] Check mirror before leaving
   374→
   375→**Weekly (Sunday Reset):**
   376→- [ ] Trim nose/ear hair
   377→- [ ] Eyebrow cleanup
   378→- [ ] Facial hair maintenance
   379→- [ ] Nail trim
   380→- [ ] Deep clean ears
   381→
   382→**Monthly:**
   383→- [ ] Haircut
   384→- [ ] Replace toothbrush head
   385→- [ ] Inventory grooming supplies
   386→
   387→**This is the baseline.** This is what separates "that guy takes care of himself" from "what's that smell?"
   388→
   389→Lock in.`,
   390→    },
   391→  ],
   392→};
   393→

<system-reminder>

/**
 * General Maintenance Guide
 * Humor Level: High (25%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const maintenanceGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'maintenance',
  slug: 'general-maintenance',
  title: 'General Maintenance',
  subtitle: "The bare minimum that most guys still somehow miss",
  description: "Daily and weekly grooming habits that separate you from the NPCs. Non-negotiable baseline stuff.",
  icon: 'Wrench',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 10,
  order: 2,
  tags: ['grooming', 'hygiene', 'daily-routine', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['mindset', 'skincare'],
  productIds: [
    'tongue_scraper',
    'electric_toothbrush',
    'philips_oneblade',
    'nose_trimmer',
    'tweezers',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'cologne_bleu',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'fashion',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'maintenance-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1519085360753-af0119f7cbe7?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clean, well-groomed appearance',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The NPC Baseline',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Here's something that might hurt: most guys walking around have absolutely no idea how many basic maintenance things they're neglecting.

Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation. Crusty lips. Unibrow situation developing. Breath that could clear a room.

**Nobody tells you this stuff.** Your friends won't. Your family's given up. Tinder matches just unmatch without explanation.

This guide is the checklist. The bare minimum. The "if you're not doing this, nothing else matters" baseline.

Everything here is simple. Nothing is expensive. No excuses.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-oral',
      title: 'Daily: Oral Hygiene',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Your breath is out here committing war crimes and you don't even know it.

**The Protocol:**
1. **Brush 2x daily** — Electric toothbrush, 2 minutes minimum. If you're using a manual toothbrush in 2024, that's NPC behavior.
2. **Floss daily** — Yes, actually. The stuff between your teeth is rotting. Get string floss or a water flosser.
3. **Tongue scrape** — This is the secret weapon. 70% of bad breath comes from bacteria on your tongue. Takes 10 seconds, changes everything.

**The Reality Check:**
- You can't smell your own breath
- Everyone's too polite to tell you
- This is actively limiting your social and romantic life
- Fix it now`,
      products: ['tongue_scraper', 'electric_toothbrush'],
      tips: [
        'Scrape tongue BEFORE brushing, not after',
        'Replace toothbrush head every 3 months',
        'Mouthwash is optional but flossing is mandatory'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tongue-scraping',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1606107557195-0e29a4b5b4aa?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Oral hygiene and dental care products',
          caption: 'Oral hygiene: brush, floss, scrape',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'daily-lips',
      title: 'Daily: Lip Care',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Crusty, chapped lips are sabotaging your entire face. The fix costs $5.

**Why This Matters:**
Your lips are one of the first things people notice. Dry, cracked lips read as "doesn't take care of himself" instantly.

**The Fix:**
- Apply lip balm or Aquaphor morning and night
- Reapply after eating or drinking
- At night, use a heavier occlusive (Aquaphor > chapstick)

**Common Mistakes:**
- Licking your lips (makes it worse)
- Flavored lip balms (you'll lick them)
- Forgetting entirely (check your lips right now)

**Pro tip:** Keep one by your bed, one in your pocket, one at your desk. The best lip balm is the one you actually use.`,
      products: ['aquaphor_lip'],
    },
    {
      id: 'weekly-nose-ear',
      title: 'Weekly: Nose & Ear Hair',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Nostril tentacles waving at people mid-conversation is an instant mog-killer. Nobody's going to tell you—they'll just slowly lose attraction and not know why.

**The Protocol:**
- Trim nose hairs weekly (Sunday maintenance)
- Check ear hair too (yes, you have some)
- Use a proper trimmer, not scissors (you WILL cut yourself)

**The Psychology:**

**What to Do:**
1. **Define the gap** — There should be clear separation between brows. Pluck strays between them.
2. **Clean the edges** — Remove random hairs above and below the brow line.

**What NOT to Do:**

- Don't wax (too aggressive for maintenance)

**The Goal:**

**Stubble:**

**Beard:**

**The Standard:**
- Trim weekly

- Clean under nails daily

**What You're Avoiding:**

      content: `Stop smelling like your high school gym locker. This ain't Axe bodyspray era anymore.

**The Layers:**
1. **Base** — Shower daily with unscented or lightly scented soap
2. **Deodorant** — Antiperspirant, applied at night (not morning)

**Application:**

**Timeline:**

   412→## Why Maintenance Is Hard
   413→
   414→- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
   415→- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
   416→- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
   417→- Life happens
   418→
   419→## The Strategy
   420→
   421→1. **Reverse diet** — Slowly increase calories after cutting
   422→2. **Stay active** — NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
   423→3. **Keep tracking** — At least loosely, forever
   424→4. **Set a ceiling** — "I never go above 15%" as a rule
   425→
   426→---
   427→
   428→## The Buffer Zone
   429→
   430→Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.
   431→
   432→Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.
   433→
   434→## The Long Game
   435→
   436→> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.
   437→
   438→Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
   439→    },
   440→    {
   441→      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
   442→      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
   443→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   444→      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:
   445→
   446→**The Face Fat Timeline:**
   447→
   448→| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
   449→|------------|-------------|--------------|

   451→| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
   452→| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
   453→| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
   454→| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
   455→| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
   456→| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |
   457→
   458→**The Critical Threshold:**
   459→For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lighting—this is why.
   460→
   461→**Why Your Face Is Last:**
   462→Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.
   463→
   464→**The Individual Factor:**
   465→Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is genetics—work with what you have, not against it.
   466→
   467→**The Math:**
   468→If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
   469→      media: [
   470→        {
   471→          id: 'bf-face-progression',
   472→          type: 'image',
   473→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597223557154-721c1cecc4b0?w=800&q=80',
   474→          alt: 'Lean face definition example',

   482→      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
   483→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   484→      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:
   485→
   486→**Men's Fat Loss Order:**
   487→
   488→| Order | Area | When It Goes |
   489→|-------|------|--------------|
   490→| 1st | Arms, shoulders | First few weeks |
   491→| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
   492→| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
   493→| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
   494→| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
   495→| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
   496→| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |
   497→
   498→Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.
   499→
   500→**Women's Fat Loss Order:**
   501→
   502→| Order | Area | When It Goes |
   503→|-------|------|--------------|
   504→| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
   505→| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
   506→| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
   507→| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
   508→| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
   509→| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
   510→| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |
   511→
   512→Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.
   513→
   514→**The Implications:**
   515→- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
   516→- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.
   517→
   518→**Stubborn Fat Science:**
   519→"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't work—you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.
   520→
   521→The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,
   522→    },
   523→    {
   524→      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
   525→      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
   526→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   527→      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:
   528→
   529→**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
   530→Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.
   531→
   532→**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**
   533→
   534→**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
   535→- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
   536→- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
   537→- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
   538→- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
   539→- Stimulant—not for everyone
   540→
   541→**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
   542→- Freezes and kills fat cells
   543→- 20-25% fat reduction per session
   544→- Multiple sessions needed
   545→- Cost: $600-1,200 per area

   547→- Non-invasive
   548→
   549→**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
   550→- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
   551→- Dissolves fat cells permanently
   552→- 2-4 sessions needed
   553→- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
   554→- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment
   555→
   556→**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**
   557→
   558→The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:
   559→
   560→| Factor | Details |
   561→|--------|---------|
   562→| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
   563→| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
   564→| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
   565→| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
   566→| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
   567→| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |
   568→
   569→**Types of Liposuction:**
   570→- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
   571→- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
   572→- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
   573→- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost
   574→
   575→**Critical Point:**
   576→Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.
   577→
   578→**Medical Tourism:**
   579→Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,
   580→      warnings: [
   581→        'Liposuction at high body fat % leads to uneven results',
   582→        'Fat can redistribute to other areas if you gain weight post-lipo',
   583→        'Always verify surgeon credentials and see real before/afters'
   584→      ],
   585→    },
   586→    {
   587→      id: 'common-mistakes',
   588→      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
   589→      humorLevel: 'high',
   590→      content: `Don't be this guy:
   591→
   592→---
   593→
   594→## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast
   595→
   596→*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*
   597→
   598→**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.
   599→
   600→---
   601→
   602→## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein
   603→
   604→*"I'm just not going to eat much."*
   605→
   606→**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.
   607→
   608→---
   609→
   610→## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats
   611→
   612→*"I was good all week!"*
   613→
   614→**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.
   615→
   616→---
   617→
   618→## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories
   619→
   620→*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*
   621→
   622→**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.
   623→
   624→---
   625→
   626→## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training
   627→
   628→*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*
   629→
   630→**Result:** Lost 20 lbs—15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.
   631→
   632→---
   633→
   634→## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale
   635→
   636→*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*
   637→
   638→**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.
   639→
   640→---
   641→
   642→Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,
   643→    },
   644→    {
   645→      id: 'action-plan',
   646→      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   647→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   648→      content: `Here's exactly what to do:
   649→
   650→---
   651→
   652→## Step 1: Establish Baseline
   653→
   654→- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
   655→- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
   656→- Take photos in consistent lighting
   657→
   658→## Step 2: Set Up Tracking
   659→
   660→- Download a calorie tracking app
   661→- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
   662→- Set protein and calorie targets
   663→
   664→## Step 3: Start the Cut
   665→
   666→- 300-500 calorie deficit
   667→- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
   668→- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)
   669→
   670→## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust
   671→
   672→- Weigh daily, average weekly
   673→- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
   674→- Take weekly photos in same conditions
   675→
   676→## Step 5: Be Patient
   677→
   678→- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
   679→- Facial changes come last—don't quit early
   680→- Adjust timeline based on actual progress
   681→
   682→---
   683→
   684→## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,
   685→      products: ['food_scale'],
   686→    },
   687→  ],

/**
 * Body Fat Mastery Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium-High (20%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const bodyFatGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'body-fat',
  slug: 'body-fat-mastery',
  title: 'Body Fat Mastery',
  subtitle: "Your jawline is in there somewhere—go find it",
  description: "The single biggest lever for facial aesthetics. Going from 18% to 12% body fat transforms your face.",
  icon: 'TrendingDown',
  humorLevel: 'medium-high',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 3,
  tags: ['body-fat', 'cutting', 'diet', 'facial-aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['diet', 'v-taper', 'training'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'face-fat',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'bodyfat-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019613454-1cb2f99b2d8b?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Body fat transformation showing facial definition improvement',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Truth About Body Fat and Your Face',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `At 18% body fat, you're hoping good lighting saves you. At 11%, you ARE the good lighting.

Here's the brutal truth: you can have god-tier bone structure, but if it's buried under a layer of subcutaneous fat, you're frauding yourself out of your own genetics.

---

## Lean is life. Your jawline knows it.

This isn't about being skinny. It's about being lean enough that your facial features actually show:

- **Jawline definition** — The #1 facial aesthetic improvement
- **Cheekbone projection** — Creates that hollow, chiseled look
- **Under-eye area** — No puffy fat pads
- **Neck/chin separation** — Clean, sharp profile

Most guys have never seen their own bone structure because they've never been lean enough.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'face-fat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583454110551-21f2fa2afe61?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean athletic physique showing definition',
          caption: 'The same bone structure at 18% vs 12% body fat',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bf-ranges',
      title: 'Body Fat Percentage Breakdown',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's be honest about what each range actually looks like:

| Body Fat % | What You See | Face Impact |
|------------|--------------|-------------|
| **20%+** | Soft everywhere, no definition | Buried jaw, soft cheeks, possible double chin |
| **17-20%** | Some definition in good lighting | Jaw visible but soft, face holds water |
| **14-17%** | Visible abs in good lighting | Decent definition, not optimal |
| **12-14%** | Abs visible standing | Good facial definition, jaw pops |
| **10-12%** | Clear 6-pack, veins showing | Excellent definition, cheekbones visible |
| **8-10%** | Shredded, stage-ready | Maximum facial definition |
| **<8%** | Competition lean | Hard to maintain, not realistic long-term |

---

## The Sweet Spot: 10-14%

This is where you're lean enough for facial definition but not so lean that you're constantly hungry, weak, and irritable.

Most guys should aim for this range.

Below 10% is diminishing returns unless you're competing or doing a photoshoot.`,
      tips: [
        'Take photos in neutral lighting to assess—bathroom mirror lighting lies',
        'Measure waist circumference as a simple tracking metric',
        'DEXA scans are the gold standard for accuracy',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-visual-guide',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://www.builtlean.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/body-fat-percentage-men-759x1024.jpg',
          alt: 'Male body fat percentage visual comparison chart',
          caption: 'Visual guide: What each body fat percentage actually looks like',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'where-fat-stores',
      title: 'Where Fat Stores (And Why Your Face Suffers)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:

---

## First to Store (Last to Lose)

These are the stubborn areas:

- Lower belly
- Love handles
- Lower back
- **Face (buccal area, under chin)**

## Last to Store (First to Lose)

These lean out quickly:

- Arms
- Upper chest
- Calves

---

## What This Means

Your face is often one of the **LAST** places to lean out.

This is why guys at 18% think *"I'm not even that fat"* while their jaw is still buried.

## The Face Tax

If you carry fat in your face (many people do), you might need to get leaner than average to see facial definition.

Someone might have a visible 6-pack at 14%, but their face doesn't pop until 11%.

It's not fair. It's genetics. Work with it.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'fat-distribution',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019614242-c5c5dee9f50b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete with lean physique',
          caption: 'Common fat storage patterns - face fat is often the last to go',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'measuring',
      title: 'How to Actually Measure Body Fat',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:

---

## Tier 1: DEXA Scan (Most Accurate)

- $50-150 at clinics
- Tells you exactly where fat is distributed
- Worth getting once to establish baseline

## Tier 2: Calipers (Decent If Done Right)

- $15 for calipers
- 7-site measurement protocol
- Requires practice and consistency
- ±3% error margin

## Tier 3: Navy Method (Free, Okay)

- Uses neck and waist measurements
- Formula-based estimate
- Better than nothing

## Tier 4: Bioelectrical Impedance (Mostly Useless)

- Those scales and gym machines
- Varies wildly based on hydration
- Can be off by 5-10%
- Only useful for tracking trends, not absolute numbers

## Tier 5: Mirror + Photos (Subjective But Real)

- Compare to reference photos at known body fat %
- Track progress over time
- Lighting consistent, same time of day

---

**Recommendation:** Get a DEXA scan once, then track via photos and waist measurement.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-math',
      title: 'The Fat Loss Equation',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `This is simple math. Not easy, but simple.

---

## The Formula

> **Calories In < Calories Out = Fat Loss**

That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.

---

## Setting Your Deficit

1. Calculate maintenance calories (TDEE)
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Adjust based on results

## Rate of Loss

| Goal | Rate | Weekly Deficit |
|------|------|----------------|
| **Sustainable** | 0.5-1% of bodyweight/week | 300-500 cal/day |
| **Aggressive** | 1-1.5% of bodyweight/week | 500-750 cal/day |
| **Too Fast** | >1.5% of bodyweight/week | Muscle loss risk |

---

## For a 180lb guy:

- **Target:** 0.9-1.8 lbs per week
- **Deficit:** 450-900 calories daily
- **Timeline:** 10 lbs of fat takes 5-10 weeks minimum

**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,
      tips: [
        '500 calorie deficit = ~1 lb fat loss per week',
        'Weigh daily, average weekly (weight fluctuates)',
        "If you're not losing, you're eating more than you think",
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein-priority',
      title: 'Protein: The Non-Negotiable',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.

---

## Why Protein Matters

- **Preserves muscle mass** during deficit
- **Most satiating** macronutrient (keeps you full)
- **Highest thermic effect** (burns calories to digest)
- **Prevents** the "skinny fat" look

## How Much

| Bodyweight | Daily Protein Target |
|------------|---------------------|
| 150 lbs | 120-150g |
| 180 lbs | 144-180g |
| 200 lbs | 160-200g |
| 220 lbs | 176-220g |

Yes, this seems like a lot. Yes, it's necessary.

---

## Example Day (180g protein)

| Meal | Foods | Protein |
|------|-------|---------|
| **Breakfast** | 4 eggs + greek yogurt | 40g |
| **Lunch** | 8oz chicken breast + cottage cheese | 60g |
| **Dinner** | 8oz salmon + protein shake | 60g |
| **Snack** | Protein bar | 20g |
| **TOTAL** | | **180g** |

If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'water-and-bloat',
      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you.

Your face is literally retaining fluid to compensate.

---

## The Paradox

> Drink **MORE** water to hold **LESS** water.

Your body retains fluid when dehydrated.

## The Protocol

| Bodyweight | Daily Water Target |
|------------|-------------------|
| 150 lbs | 75 oz (2.2L) |
| 180 lbs | 90 oz (2.7L) |
| 200 lbs | 100 oz (3L) |
| 220 lbs | 110 oz (3.3L) |

Add more if training or sweating.

---

## What Causes Facial Bloat

| Cause | Effect | Fix |
|-------|--------|-----|
| **Sodium** | High salt = water retention | Keep moderate, not zero |
| **Alcohol** | Dehydrates, then overcompensates | Limit or eliminate |
| **Carbs** | Each gram stores 3-4g of water | Expected, not bad |
| **Sleep deprivation** | Cortisol = water retention | Get 7-8 hours |
| **Dehydration** | Counter-intuitive but true | Drink more water |

---

## The Morning Difference

Ever notice you look leaner in the morning?

You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weight—it makes a visible difference.

For consistent leanness, stay consistently hydrated and keep sodium moderate.`,
      products: ['water_jug'],
      tips: [
        'Drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking',
        'Cut sodium 24-48 hours before photos for temporary tightness',
        "Alcohol is the worst for next-day face bloat",
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bloat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1548690312-e3b507d8c110?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy hydration and fitness',
          caption: 'Same person: bloated vs properly hydrated',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'timeline',
      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:

---

## Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)

- **Goal:** 12% body fat
- **Fat to lose:** ~15 lbs
- **Timeline:** 10-15 weeks (doing it right)

---

## Week by Week Progress

| Weeks | What Happens | What You See |
|-------|--------------|--------------|
| **1-2** | Water weight drops | Scale moves fast, exciting |
| **3-6** | Steady fat loss | Starting to see changes |
| **7-10** | Face starts tightening | Jaw appearing, cheekbones hint |
| **11-15** | Final stubborn fat burns | Face pops, transformation complete |

---

## The Trap

Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit.

Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.

## The Reality

> Fat loss in the face often happens in the **final phase**.

You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly *"damn, there's my jawline."*

Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
      warnings: [
        "Don't cut harder because the scale slowed—you'll lose muscle",
        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'timeline-progress',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1517836357463-d25dfeac3438?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Visual timeline of fitness progress',
          caption: '12-week transformation: patience is key',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'maintaining',
      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.

---

## Why Maintenance Is Hard

- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
- Life happens

## The Strategy

1. **Reverse diet** — Slowly increase calories after cutting
2. **Stay active** — NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
3. **Keep tracking** — At least loosely, forever
4. **Set a ceiling** — "I never go above 15%" as a rule

---

## The Buffer Zone

Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.

Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.

## The Long Game

> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.

Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:

**The Face Fat Timeline:**

| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
|------------|-------------|--------------|
| **25%+** | Maximum bloat | Round face, double chin likely, jaw completely hidden |
| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |

**The Critical Threshold:**
For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lighting—this is why.

**Why Your Face Is Last:**
Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.

**The Individual Factor:**
Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is genetics—work with what you have, not against it.

**The Math:**
If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-face-progression',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597223557154-721c1cecc4b0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean face definition example',
          caption: 'The same bone structure reveals itself at lower body fat',
          placement: 'inline',

    {
      id: 'fat-loss-order',
      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:

**Men's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Arms, shoulders | First few weeks |
| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |

Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.

**Women's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |

Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.

**The Implications:**
- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.

**Stubborn Fat Science:**
"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't work—you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.

The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,

      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:

**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.

**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**

**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
- Stimulant—not for everyone

**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
- Freezes and kills fat cells
- 20-25% fat reduction per session
- Multiple sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per area
- Results in 2-3 months
- Non-invasive

**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
- Dissolves fat cells permanently
- 2-4 sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment

**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**

The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:

| Factor | Details |
|--------|---------|
| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |

**Types of Liposuction:**
- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost

**Critical Point:**
Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.

**Medical Tourism:**
Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,

      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

---

## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast

*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*

**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.

---

## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein

*"I'm just not going to eat much."*

**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.

---

## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats

*"I was good all week!"*

**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.

---

## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories

*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*

**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.

---

## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training

*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*

**Result:** Lost 20 lbs—15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.

---

## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale

*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*

**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.

---

Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,

      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

---

## Step 1: Establish Baseline

- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
- Take photos in consistent lighting

## Step 2: Set Up Tracking

- Download a calorie tracking app
- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
- Set protein and calorie targets

## Step 3: Start the Cut

- 300-500 calorie deficit
- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)

## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust

- Weigh daily, average weekly
- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
- Take weekly photos in same conditions

## Step 5: Be Patient

- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
- Facial changes come last—don't quit early
- Adjust timeline based on actual progress

---

## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,

   415→- Measure shoulder and waist circumference monthly
   416→- Take progress photos (back and side views)
   417→- Track your lifting numbers for progressive overload
   418→
   419→**Supplementation:**
   420→- Creatine for strength and fullness
   421→- Protein for muscle building
   422→- That's it—no magic pills for width
   423→
   424→The V-taper is earned, not given. Start building it now.`,
   425→      products: ['creatine_mono', 'collagen_peptides'],
   426→    },
   427→  ],
   428→};
